summary: This is an internal FBI email chain from September 2019 discussing victim compensation for Epstein victims. It involves FBI personnel in New York and the Department of Justice's Office for Victims of Crime (OVS), seeking guidance on whether victims who recently disclosed abuse can still apply for compensation, contingent on a prosecutorial letter from the SDNY.

persons.name: Cronin
persons.context: An employee from the Office for Victims of Crime (OVS) who responds to an FBI inquiry, stating that victim compensation may be possible if a letter from a DA or AUSA confirms they would have prosecuted the case if brought timely.

events.title: OVS Inquiry on Epstein Victim Compensation
events.description: An FBI agent emails the Office for Victims of Crime (OVS) asking if victims who recently disclosed abuse by Epstein can still apply for compensation, given the timing of their disclosure.

events.title: FBI Victim Services Request to SDNY
events.description: The FBI Victim Services Division forwards a request to the Southern District of New York (SDNY) regarding a letter needed for victim compensation, as advised by OVS.

events.title: Follow-up on Epstein Victim Compensation
events.description: An FBI agent in New York follows up on the status of obtaining information or a letter regarding victim compensation for Epstein victims.

keyFacts: The FBI was actively working with multiple Epstein victims in the New York City area as of September 2019.

The Office for Victims of Crime indicated compensation for victims might be possible if a letter from a District Attorney or Assistant U.S. Attorney stated they would have prosecuted the case if it had been brought in a timely manner.
The email chain shows coordination between FBI field offices (NY), the FBI Victim Services Division, and the Department of Justice's OVS regarding victim support.
The correspondence references an event 'over the weekend' that made an OVS representative 'so angry,' likely alluding to Jeffrey Epstein's death in August 2019.
The document highlights procedural hurdles for victims seeking compensation, specifically the need for formal prosecutorial endorsement.
